original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished: Another week flew by. I drove past the new house yesterday—the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing; I’m thrilled. If all goes well, we’ll close a week from Wednesday. Last night, Bethany and I stayed up past 3:00 AM watching movies. Lately, we’ve been watching a lot. Here’s the rundown: first, *Thirteen*—every teen’s mother should see it. It was better than expected. Then *Gigli*—just as bad as the reviews claimed, but we had to see for ourselves.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished: Summer TV used to be a dead zone full of repeats, but now there are two great new shows I’ve been watching religiously. *Blow Out*—the gayest concept ever with seemingly zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist Jonathan Antin wants to open a second location for his popular West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Normally, no one would care—certainly not me—but while flipping channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan, equally narcissistic and dull, staring at an empty space on Rodeo Dr. declaring (loudly), "I’m going to build the greatest salon in history!" And I was hooked. Not since Rocco has such a moron made for compelling TV.

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished: What a week... My right shoulder has tendinitis, right under the shoulder blade. Moving my arm too much—especially while using a computer mouse—is agonizing. I overdid it updating my website and working online, so now I can barely move it. Finding the energy to draw feels impossible. The lack of sleep only worsens the pain. I’m not in the best spirits, but I’ll recover. My mom’s surgery went well—her eyesight has improved slightly. She can see blurry shapes and distinguish colors, though she’s still mostly blind. Hopefully, her vision will fully return soon.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished: The kindness of strangers... Today, I attempted laundry with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest tasks can turn into an ordeal. I also discovered how incredibly sweet strangers can be—simply because they choose to be kind. Trust me, it wasn’t about ulterior motives. I was covered in kid drool and wearing my "wash-day" outfit... Plus, I’m not entirely sure I’ll ever bathe again, so there wasn’t even an olfactory incentive! Right now, I’m doing two things: composing this post and watching No Doubt’s greatest hits. Both from the comfort of my desk.

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished: It’s 11:14 PM MST, and here I sit in my bedroom fixing the personnel director’s computer from work. I don’t mind helping, but I often wonder how frequently I end up repairing someone else’s device as a favor. While I’m happy to serve others this way, where do you draw the line before feeling taken advantage of? Lately, I’ve been staying up late reading, so I was eager to sleep early—until I realized it’d be wiser to return this computer sooner. *laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So tonight, I’m rewatching *Joe Schmo 2*.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished: Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation of the 'Is this a date?' saga. After the awkward lunch, my confidence wavered, and I forgot to share a key detail. Before Pat arrived, Dustin started praising him, mentioning how he was trying to find him a girlfriend. I listened, nodding, but soon realized we were focusing more on setting Pat up than having a normal conversation with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, glanced in the mirror, and wondered: Am I being pawned off to the other guy? Is this really happening?

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: I wish everyone would think before they act. In fact, I’d love for every single person to pause before getting out of bed each morning and commit to staying thoughtful all day. If they’re unwilling to do that, I’d prefer they just stay in bed forever. I’m exhausted by foolishness. No, I’m not the brightest person alive—but I’m not talking about complex matters, so it’s fair to criticize sheer stupidity. Let’s focus this rant on a few specific types for now and save the rest for another day. Sound good? Great.

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished:
Two issues with the scenario from my previous post:  
1. While Bush is stimulating the economy, his approach is flawed. As Robert Rubin noted on NPR's *Marketplace*, Bush could have achieved the same effect without long-term debt by implementing temporary tax cuts for low- and middle-income earners. Ah, Robert Rubin—his name alone inspires confidence. Quick: name a Bush administration domestic official with Rubin’s gravitas. Still thinking? It’ll come to you...  
2. We can’t cede control to Republicans solely during wartime—they’ve cleverly engineered an endless global "war on terror.

original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished: Have you ever had one of those moments when you start reflecting on life? Like sitting in math class, utterly bored, wondering how your brain even processes math? Then you realize you exist—right there, in math class—and question why. Suddenly, you grasp how incredible existence is, only to feel pathetic for spiraling into random thoughts. Ever experienced that? I despise it. And you know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who thought that was a good idea? Sitting through a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is clearly cruel and unusual punishment.

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished: I think Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow never to touch that cursed iron piece (the game token, not the hot one) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few dollars and won the frustrating game—or maybe I let him win since he’s leaving soon, and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However the story goes, it pales in comparison to this Texas-sized headache I have now. I’ve taken some Aleve, and it’s helping, but all I need is some well-deserved R&R. *"Your telephone’s the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck..." — At the Drive-In*

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. polished: Well... Today has been a long day. We drove home from Indiana, and I’ll need to be selective about what I write because I don’t have much energy. First, camp was incredible—even better than I expected. God has been working in my life lately, and it’s been amazing. I’ve turned over a new leaf, but back to the start. We arrived at the Twiggs’ house Friday evening and stayed until leaving for camp on Monday. Most of our time was spent at the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watching movies.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished: Today is my last day of summer vacation—waaaaaa! I have a dentist appointment at 9, which I dread, but I’d rather get it done now than during my surgery rotation. I’m nervous, scared, jittery—basically every synonym for "I really don’t want to go back to school." This will be a whole new challenge for me. As a perfectionist, I thrive on excelling, but starting something new is tough. I hate feeling like a pawn (as I told Cassie: "I’ll be the pawn insisting on moving like a knight"), and I despise not knowing what’s coming.

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Arun Shourie highlights how the current Uttar Pradesh governor had warned as early as 1996 about the potential rise of a 'third Islamic state' in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, former Intelligence Bureau chief and present governor, predicted this grave threat in a series of Hindustan Times articles back then. Shourie poses a compelling question: Does knowing that Rajeswar—not him or Mr. Advani—authored these warnings lend them credibility? Or does it imply that Rajeswar, by repeating this concern, is a closet communalist unfit to remain governor?

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished: For the past two days, I’ve been overwhelmed by terrible exhaustion—bone-deep fatigue. Last evening, I went home and slept immediately, only waking when my mother called around eight-thirty. When I opened my eyes, it was pitch dark—I hadn’t turned on the lights—so for a moment, I couldn’t tell the time or date. There was just my mother’s voice in the darkness as I struggled to grasp reality. I wonder why I feel so drained... Lovely weather this morning. It was drizzling when I arrived, though I hear it’s been raining in Calcutta for three days straight.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished: Last night was terrible. I discarded the sweater I was knitting after completing only 14 inches. I wasted around $10 worth of yarn (at $8 per skein). By the armholes, the stitch count was off, and the mohair kept tangling as I worked. Frogging proved ineffective—the yarn kept snapping. Oddly, I didn’t even swear. Instead, I gloomily unraveled rows while listening to *Sex and the City* (thanks, library!). Eventually, frustration won, and I tossed it. Still, I suppose I learned a lot from this sweater attempt.

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: Last night in class, we discussed the week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World* by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement," while the second examines "displacement." Casey argues that modern culture prioritizes time as the organizing force—evident in phrases like "running out of time" or "saving time." He suggests centering culture around place instead, fostering a more grounded community. (This is a rough summary—disclaimer in case my professor or classmates read this.) So far, this book is the first to truly captivate me.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. polished: Whatever they put into freeze pops to create those vibrant colors should come with a warning: *may make life delightfully bizarre*. Though laughter is wonderful, one can’t help but wonder if we’d have ended up on that fire escape, sipping beer in the howling wind, had we not eaten them earlier. Stumbling upon a shuttered bar, we paused to flip through an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the mail. Lucky we did—who could’ve guessed it held the deals of a lifetime? Certainly not me. A few highlights: buy 36 permanent markers, get a stunt kite; purchase 30 lever arch files, score a barbecue.

I’ll admit, I didn’t... well, maybe I tuned in briefly. original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished: This was a great weekend. I enjoyed a lot of nature’s bounty, revisited Nevermore’s music (long overdue), and immersed myself in reading. I finished three books: Bruce Sterling’s *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven’s *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler’s *Parable of the Sower*. *Heavy Weather* was a thrilling cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future USA ravaged by climate chaos and societal collapse. Though clever, well-paced, and convincingly crafted, I didn’t walk away deeply moved by its story or characters. Not that they weren’t vividly drawn—it’s a solid book, just not a masterpiece.

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished: Because this is the aftermath. The first week back from practicum was a struggle, but only in the second week has the smoke truly begun to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic now coming to light. I was overwhelmed, but meeting with the course coordinator helped me release my burden, preventing another student from enduring such a pedagogically deficient practicum school. Yesterday (Monday), I encountered another distressed classmate determined to warn the next student assigned to her school about how terrible it would be. I calmed her, suggesting we approach the administrator first.

original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished: Fall 1974: I was attempting—for what felt like the thirteenth time—to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I despise math. I am math-phobic. You get the idea. As I struggled to grasp algebra, the doorbell rang. I set my book aside and answered the door. No one was there. Perfect. I returned to my studies, and just as a glimmer of understanding surfaced, the doorbell rang again. Bam—my breakthrough vanished. I checked once more, but no one was there. Exactly what a struggling math student needs: an uninvited prankster.

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, these are the things i need to consider as i spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: This past week has been exhausting. I spent Tuesday through Thursday moving to my new classroom, which is larger and closer to my grade-level team—key factors as I prepare for the year. Had I known about the move earlier, I would have discarded unused books and supplies. Instead, everything came with me, so this week involved moving, unpacking, and purging relentlessly. I’m incredibly grateful to my teammate Jill for her help. Despite still teaching in my old classroom this month, she and her wonderful students moved nearly everything for me!

polished: You can’t escape it: a part of you will always live in me. Even if I never bore your child, even if we never married, even if we were never an official pair... I loved you deeply, and that feeling still echoes in my heart. Forever, I’ll remember the few nights we shared, hearts and limbs entwined in a soulful embrace, bathed in the salty darkness of a beach evening... or a kiss in the rain. Whenever I feel a sharp ache pierce my heart, you’ll be there—that piece of you, bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me... and still remains. For her.

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.
polished: I'm uneasy. Investigative reporting feels very wrong to me—or rather, the article I'm working on and its consequences aren't something I'm entirely comfortable with. Maybe it's because I don't fully believe in it, so I can't grasp the true essence of it—the underlying passion to question everything. I grew up in a country where asking questions wasn't an option. They'd shoot you for that. They'd jail you under internal security acts. I'm not accustomed to this freedom of speech...not used to voicing doubts openly. Admittedly, I'm not the easiest person to get along with.

original: We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We went to guintubdan, la carolota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked for the falls. It was a 30 minute or so walk. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. The water was chilly ice. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. We only stayed less than an hour because we headed for the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it because the falls looked calming and the whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you be lulled to sleep.
polished: We had an outing yesterday with my colleagues from the bank. We visited Guintubdan, La Carlota—a first for most of us. The trek to the falls took about 30 minutes, leaving us breathless, but we persevered. The water was icy cold, numbing our bodies within moments. We stayed briefly before heading to nearby waterfalls after another 30-minute hike. The effort was worthwhile—the falls were serene, and the scenery truly breathtaking. It felt like becoming one with nature, as if you could hear your own harmony with the surroundings. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth. The crisp air and water were so soothing, they could lull you to sleep.

polished:
Some people are quick to connect this dot: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. Observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This marks the first time such a team will attend a U.S. presidential election.  

Meanwhile, a group of congressional Democrats, including four New Yorkers, petitioned U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to send international observers to Florida for this year's presidential balloting. I respectfully disagree. Based on available information, the OSCE appears to be here to learn from the U.S. election process—not oversee it, unlike the initial partisan and misguided call for U.N. involvement.

original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished:
GOP Faces Criticism Over Recruitment  
Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are being relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy  

The Jacksonville citizenship ceremony appeared routine, with nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Before leaving the June 29 event, an immigration official encouraged attendees to visit a voter registration table—a common practice. However, this table was unusual: Republican volunteers distributed forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked, automatically enrolling new voters as GOP members.  

Linda Cross, there to witness her husband Dario Cruz’s oath, found the situation suspicious.

polished: I have always prided myself on making everyone who frequents Casa Pescatore as comfortable as possible. I want them to feel at home, just as they would in their own residence. Yesterday—I hope I succeeded. The crowd gathered on Perry Ave with what many would call 'extreme prejudice.' At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, the food I prepared was ready, and the atmosphere was electric. Before I knew it, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, bringing an instant smile to my face. I had missed him so much. The bonus? His wife joined him—she’s expecting, and this is the closest I’ll get to being an uncle. I spoiled her with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished: I liked the idea of that as an offense—perhaps it could’ve been a way to avoid being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I’ve hesitated to engage in certain discussions, especially those about flags. But since I started the topic (the subject, not flag-burning), I should probably weigh in. First, I believe outlawing flag-burning is absurd. The moment you grant any symbol automatic reverence and legal protection, you take a small but significant step toward totalitarianism. Symbols are fickle—they don’t inherently represent anything; their meaning lies in perception and interpretation.

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. polished: Hello, so I saw *Troy* tonight with my family... I wasn’t impressed. I’m too tired to delve into specifics, but it did have potential. Additionally, the score felt lackluster—a poor imitation of *Gladiator*. *Gladiator* used a moaning woman’s vocals effectively, complementing its compelling narrative.

polished: Urllink welcomes the newest Atom/RSS/RDF reader on the scene: PulpFiction 1.0 from Freshly Squeezed Software. Packed with native app features, it’s worth noting this isn’t a free offering—a recurring debate online. You can test it for 15 days before deciding to switch back or purchase it for $25. polished: Ever had one of those days when you just don’t know... anything? No? Then skip the rest—this won’t make sense to you. For those continuing, here’s an observation: *Sometimes I wish I’d been given the manual.* A good manual tells you: what things are for, what they can do, how they work, what happens if you press button X or Y, troubleshooting steps, and the contact details of an all-knowing guru. Very useful. Sadly, I didn’t come with one.

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished: There’s nothing wrong with PCs—if I were a dedicated gamer with time to spare, I’d definitely own a PC for its vast library. Yet, aside from a few standout titles, that massive wall of games at CompUSA grows repetitive over time. At first, I’m envious, but then I realize it’s just endless variations of the same formula—first-person shooters, mysteries, strategy games, and simulations. The sheer number of *Age of Empires* spin-offs is almost comical. *AOE*—with orcs! *AOE*—with spaceships! *AOE*—with fuzzy wombats! It’s like those movie trailers that always begin: *"In a world..."*

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished:
**Polished Version:**  

*Jdasovic.nsf*  
Monday, December 11, 2000  

**To:** All PX Market Participants  
**From:** John Yurkanin, Chief Operating Officer  
**Re:** Loss of Continuity in PX Day-Ahead Auction Due to ISO Rule Changes  

The emergency tariff filing by the California ISO last Friday has negatively impacted the PX day-ahead auction market. The combination of soft and hard caps creates a complete disconnect, posing unacceptable risks to all participants and likely failing to achieve the ISO’s intended reduction in real-time energy sales and procurement. Ultimately, supply will still favor the higher price opportunities the ISO provides. The PX is petitioning Terry Winter of the ISO to immediately permit adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at relevant prices.

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished:
Mark Guzman 6-28-02.nsf: Just confirming you received this from Les Rawson regarding Grays Harbor and Willamette. -Bill  

Effective immediately, Enron has purchased control area reserves service from BPA. This enables services to sell unit-contingent energy as hourly firm, as BPA is supplying reserves for up to 60 minutes.  

If Grays Harbor Paper notifies RT of a unit derate or outage, RT must alert BPA dispatch immediately and adjust the schedule during the next ramp. For instance, if Grays unit trips at 1333, RT would notify BPA and the sink, reducing the 1400 schedule to zero.  

The key takeaway: BPA will only carry the schedule for a maximum of 60 minutes.

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished:
El Paso tests market for mainline expansion. El Paso Natural Gas clearly received the message when its last open season for 1.2 Bcf/d of firm transportation capacity drew bids for 14.4 Bcf/d. The pipeline has launched an open season to gauge market interest in expanding its mainline and address regulatory concerns about relieving capacity constraints at the California border.  

El Paso faces mounting pressure from regulators and shippers to expand due to surging demand and skyrocketing prices in California. In a January 3 letter, Daniel M. Adamson, director of FERC's Office of Energy Projects, urged the pipeline to modify its Line 2000 project to help alleviate the crisis in California's gas market.

original: Sscott5.nsf ahimsa (uh-him-sah) noun the principle of noninjury to living beings. [sanskrit ahimsa : a-, not + himsa, injury (from himsati, he injures).] "as my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, i became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The lines in the anthem: scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa." m.k. Gandhi, the story of my experiments with truth, 1927. Today is october 2, the day mohandas karamchand gandhi was born in the year 1869. A man born some two centuries ago may appear irrelevant to our age, but in reality his life and message are still applicable to our lives today.
polished:
**Ahimsa** (uh-him-sah) *noun*: the principle of nonviolence toward living beings. [Sanskrit *ahimsa*: *a-*, not + *himsa*, injury (from *himsati*, to injure).]  

*"As my understanding of ahimsa deepened, I grew more mindful of my thoughts and words. The anthem's lines—'Scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks'—clashed painfully with my belief in ahimsa."* —M.K. Gandhi, *The Story of My Experiments with Truth*, 1927.  

Today, October 2, marks the birth of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi in 1869. Though born over a century ago, his life and teachings remain profoundly relevant today.

polished:
Mgrigsb.nsf ? Over the weekend, Gov. Davis and Sen. Polanco reached an informal agreement, with Polanco agreeing to sponsor the SoCal MOU bill. Polanco, a Democrat, is currently embroiled in a personal scandal, effectively ending his political career. He plans to run for mayor of Los Angeles instead of seeking another Senate term.  

The bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, starting today or tomorrow. It will first go to the Senate Energy Committee. Sen. Bowen, the committee chair, strongly opposes the MOU, so the bill will likely remain in hearings for some time. The longer it stalls in committee with revisions, the higher the risk of a SoCal bankruptcy.

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished:
**SSHACKLE.NSF NOTICE NO. 00-338  
OCTOBER 3, 2000  

MEMORANDUM  

TO: All NYMEX and COMEX Members  
FROM: Neal L. Wolkoff, Executive Vice President  
DATE: October 3, 2000  
RE: Notice of CFTC Approval of New NYMEX Rule 6.40C ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants")  

Please be advised that the CFTC has approved new NYMEX Rule 6.40C ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants"), attached herein and now in effect.  

This rule, consistent with a recent CFTC advisory, allows FCMs—under specified conditions—to use their proprietary systems to generate average price (AP) calculations for orders or order series with multiple prices.**

original: Sshackle.nsf as of this week enrononline has just started offering us/canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online i look at the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and i am also looking at any board resolutions we might have received when we got the master agreement executed. What i am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions frequently the resolutions do not allow the counterparies to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us i just wanted us all to be mindful to check these old resolutions and not to rely solely on the "restrictions" contained in lotus notes.
polished:
As of this week, EnronOnline has begun offering US/Canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review to determine whether a counterparty can transact these products, I examine the financial trading agreement database for any restrictions, verify the master swap agreement, and review any board resolutions received upon execution of the master agreement.  

What I’ve found is that in the past, resolutions authorizing the master agreement or derivative transactions often did not permit counterparties to engage in currency transactions. Since trading currencies with our energy customers is a new business area, I want to ensure we remain mindful of these older resolutions and avoid relying solely on the restrictions noted in Lotus Notes.

original: Dhyvl.nsf dave, i will be glad to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, i have a number of questions. 1. Relationship of delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on northwest pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? if downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb. 2. What volume is being sold each day. You use the term dcq and you also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally their would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction. Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%.
polished:
Dear Dave,  

I’d be happy to draft the transaction agreement, but I have a few questions:  

1. **Delivery Point & Transport**: What is the relationship between the delivery point and interruptible transport on Northwest Pipeline? Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? If downstream, why isn’t EWEB contracting for it?  

2. **Daily Volume**: You mention DCQ and a 20% tolerance above/below the estimated quantity. Typically, DCQ transactions don’t include such tolerances.  

3. **Transaction Type**: Is this intended as a requirements transaction? Will the price remain the same for volumes exceeding the estimated quantity (up to an additional 20%)?  

Looking forward to your clarification.

original: Jdasovic.nsf the spreadsheet below gives the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule dr). The rate schedule effective august 2000 through september 2000 yields a much larger commodity charge because sdg&e customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from sdg&e over those two months. Sdg&e customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for june 2000 through january 2001 is 6.2 cts and the implicit commodity average from february 2001 through december 2001 is 7.3 cts. The average implicit commodity from june 2000 through december 2001 is 6.9 cts for deliveries starting september 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cts.
polished: The spreadsheet below provides the implicit commodity rates based on the effective date for four different rate schedules (Schedule DR). The rate schedule effective August 2000 through September 2000 results in a higher commodity charge, as SDG&E customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement during those two months. Consequently, customers can expect lower electric bills. Excluding the lump sum reimbursement from the implicit energy component, the average rate from June 2000 through January 2001 is 6.2 cts, while the implicit commodity average from February 2001 through December 2001 is 7.3 cts. The overall average from June 2000 through December 2001 remains 6.9 cts, including deliveries starting September 1, 2000.

original: Tdonoho (non-privileged).pst this has been a tough couple of weeks. I hope that these daily communications on new developments are helping you understand what's happening with our company. Here's a rundown of events from last week: we executed a commitment letter with jpmorgan and salomon smith barney that will provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our northern natural gas company and transwestern pipeline company will support these assets. We now have received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Our board of directors elected a new member to the board - william powers, jr., the dean of the university of texas school of law in austin, texas.
polished: This has been a challenging couple of weeks. I hope these daily updates on new developments are helping you stay informed about our company's situation. Here's a summary of last week's key events: We finalized a commitment letter with JPMorgan and Salomon Smith Barney, securing an additional $1 billion in credit lines. Our Northern Natural Gas Company and TransWestern Pipeline Company will back these assets. With this, we've now secured $4 billion in total credit lines, which we'll use to repay short-term commercial debt and ensure liquidity. Additionally, our board elected a new member—William Powers, Jr., Dean of the University of Texas School of Law in Austin.

original: Skean.nsf i am attaching the ferc order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in "potential" refunds (either pay up or provide cost justification). original: Magic fans beware... Wizards is afraid to make a decent digital game. At its core magic the gathering is a social game. A game to enjoy with your friends (or frenemies) laughing, talking smack, and dropping game winning bombs. Wizards of the coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends you cant earn gold, and gold is important. Gold is so important that they have implemented a daily cap, understandable considering gold unlocks everything in game. But get ready for a long and boring 1v1 grind against the computer or random oponents, whom you can't even speak to. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.
polished: Magic fans, beware... Wizards seems afraid to create a compelling digital game. At its core, *Magic: The Gathering* is a social experience—meant to be enjoyed with friends (or frenemies), filled with laughter, smack talk, and game-winning plays. Wizards of the Coast appears to have lost sight of this. If you play with friends, you can't earn gold, yet gold is crucial. It’s so vital that they’ve imposed a daily cap, which makes sense since gold unlocks everything. But prepare for a tedious 1v1 grind against AI or random opponents, with no way to communicate. If you play for free, expect to spend roughly four hours daily for over a month—alone—just to unlock cards.

original: Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy i'll get the bad stuff out of the way first. I quite hate pre-quals as it's technically going backwards in a story and not forwards (this is an issue for every pre-qual). Granted it offers more storywise. The combat feels sloppy and doesn't feel as sharp as arkham city managed to make it. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013) there is a game breaking bug that stops a side mission from ever being completed (main story not effected). Some gadgets are put at a rediculous hotkey that makes your hand have to travel the whole keyboard to get to it. It might sound like nothing, but while in combat it could potentially break your combo.
polished: As the third installment in the trilogy, I’ll address the negatives first. I generally dislike prequels because they move the story backward rather than forward (a common issue with prequels). While they expand the narrative, the combat here feels sloppy and lacks the precision of *Arkham City*. At the time of writing (26/10/2013), a game-breaking bug prevents completing a side mission (though the main story is unaffected). Some gadgets are assigned to awkward hotkeys, forcing your hand to stretch across the keyboard. It may seem minor, but in combat, this can disrupt your flow.

original: They basically fixed shadow warrior (2013) i.e. The bossfights are awesome, weapons feel very nice (maybe not as good as d44m's ones, but still solid), enemies aren't too spongy (if you're not too much of a retard with handling elemental and upgrade stuff). The upgrade system is really balanced and once you get around it, it's not too tedious. The elemental stuff and limited ammo softly forces you to use different weapons. Lots of cool unique (being the important word here while comparing sw2 to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ borderlands' formula of 'rng' weapons) weapons that stay viable through most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and of course stan bush's stuff.
polished: They significantly improved *Shadow Warrior* (2013). The boss fights are fantastic, and the weapons feel satisfying (though not quite as refined as *DOOM*'s, they're still solid). Enemies aren't overly spongy—unless you mishandle elemental and upgrade mechanics. The balanced upgrade system becomes intuitive without being tedious. Limited ammo and elemental effects gently encourage varied weapon use. Many unique weapons (a key distinction from *Borderlands*' RNG-driven loot) remain viable throughout. The soundtrack shines, particularly the main theme and Stan Bush's tracks.

original: So many things was made wrong. I even dont know how to start this review. This all is refered to mycareer. My player is an outside scorer, pg, 1.71m, has maxed stats and got already all necessary perks. Ok, and now tell me, why the shooting skill depends to a person's hight? why a person who has 1.74m can not became so good in shooting as a person with 1.71m? i'm 1.87m in rl, made my first player with this hight and noticed then i can not reach a higher skill than 89. Why? thats a pure discrimination! and why the game does not tell me that before i create a char and not even then when i reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?
polished: So many things were done wrong. I don’t even know where to begin with this review. This all relates to MyCareer. My player is an outside scorer—a 1.71m point guard with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Now, explain why shooting skill depends on height. Why can’t someone who’s 1.74m shoot as well as someone who’s 1.71m? I’m 1.87m in real life, so I created my first player at this height, only to discover I couldn’t exceed an 89 rating. Why? That’s pure discrimination! And why doesn’t the game warn me before character creation or even when I hit the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?

original: I think this assassin's creed nailed the mechanics down on all fronts (ship battles, sailing, hunting (fish), parkour, etc). I felt much more attached to this character as well. The story starts out extremely rough but does get much much better as you play (i think this is with every ac game personally). Edward was quite the interesting character and so was all the side characters. I felt like all the collectables actually meant something in this ac game that i never got from any of the previous ones and maybe its because i felt like they had a bigger purpose in the game. They def were not required but they were fun to get and you got rewarded in a very balanced way.
polished: I think *Assassin's Creed* perfected its mechanics across the board—ship battles, sailing, fishing, parkour, and more. I also felt a deeper connection to the protagonist. While the story starts off slow, it improves significantly as you progress (a trend I’ve noticed in most *AC* games). Edward was a compelling character, as were the supporting cast. The collectibles in this installment felt meaningful, unlike in previous games, perhaps because they served a greater purpose. They weren’t mandatory but were enjoyable to pursue, offering well-balanced rewards.

original: While i personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, so long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which would be my main complaint with this game: it's pay-to-win. If i could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and hrv is an excellent idea. I'd take this game over any call of duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransanction format is off-putting for me. If you are alright with this model, then by all means, have fun. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one slide; it's not our cup of tea.
polished: While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn’t entirely terrible. The gunplay is decent, provided you can afford the necessary upgrades—my primary criticism being its pay-to-win nature. If I could overlook that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is engaging and HRV is a brilliant concept. I’d choose this over any Call of Duty title, but its microtransaction model is a dealbreaker for me. If you’re fine with this approach, go ahead and enjoy it. But if, like me, you dislike pay-to-win mechanics, skip this one—it’s just not for us.

original: While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death leads to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and i lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. Would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a 3rd party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Plus the aiming reticule is on the small side and zoom is underpowered. With all that said, its been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first person shooter/beat em up is great. I've been playing it as often as i can get away... Just one more mission, just one more supply run - or i'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.
polished: While not perfect, this game has been incredibly enjoyable. The save system and risk of sudden death can be frustrating. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around hour 10 of 20—wishing I had a save to reload at that point. I’ve since used a third-party mod/save tool to prevent catastrophic failures. The aiming reticle is too small, and the zoom feels underpowered. Despite these flaws, it’s been a blast. I’m not usually a zombie fan, but the mix of strategy, missions, and FPS/beat-em-up gameplay is fantastic. I play as often as possible—just one more mission, one more supply run, or fleeing to safety before quitting.

original: An absolute great stragtegy game! having played every single other wargame (european escalation, and alb), i have to say this one fits well. The number of units are great. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there's a crap ton!!! graphics are just beautiful, sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The ingame chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well, no i am not kidding. However, if anyone thinking this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get it nailed down. Do not get upset, you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.
polished: An absolutely fantastic strategy game! Having played every other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I can confidently say this one stands out. The unit variety is impressive—while I don’t know the exact count, there’s a massive selection! The graphics are stunning, the sound design is excellent, and the gameplay is truly epic. The in-game chat box on the main menu is surprisingly entertaining—no joke. However, if you think this game is "easy" or are new to strategy games, expect a steep learning curve. Don’t get discouraged; you’ll lose plenty of units. Just plan carefully, prioritize anti-air and anti-tank units, and adapt.

original: I was negatively biased towards this game before i played it. Wasn't even sure about buying. polished: I was initially skeptical about this game and hesitant to buy it. The portal gun mechanic seemed odd to me, despite my love for science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The humor and voice acting are phenomenal—genuinely impressive. While occasionally cheesy, the jokes land well, and each character has a distinct sense of humor. I wouldn’t have tried this sequel otherwise.

original: Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the uk) watching the ever-irritating timmy mallet just for the five minute transformers cartoon. The voice actors for optimus, megatron, bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognisable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very generation one. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike high moon's excellent war for/fall of cybertron games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g. Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.
polished: Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) enduring the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute *Transformers* cartoon. The iconic voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and others return, instantly recognizable. The classic transformation sound is present, and the cel-shaded visuals perfectly capture Generation One’s aesthetic. Beyond nostalgia, it’s a genuinely fun game. Combat mechanics are superb, with seamless mid-fight transformations integrated into combos—setting it apart from High Moon’s *War for/Fall of Cybertron*. Another standout is the emphasis on melee, though some foes (like Seekers) demand switching to ranged attacks.

polished: I downloaded the game and played it briefly, but it was underwhelming. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing due to a bug. Worse, why force a link between Steam and GFace accounts? They claim it’s for DLC, but that seems unnecessary—and irreversible. Now a company I don’t trust has my Steam data. As for the game itself, it’s mediocre at best. It’s clearly a COD clone, yet somehow the gunplay is worse... How does that even happen?

original: I experienced no performance problems even at release, and after all these patches it plays really well. Imo, this is a really great and fun game in truth, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play batman + 1 more), and the ability to use the controller for most segments of the game but the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving your batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the apc commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you figure out how to use the breaks to skid around corners (and when you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable!)
polished: I experienced no performance issues at launch, and post-patches, it runs smoothly. Honestly, this is a fantastic and enjoyable game, though the free-roam city resetting enemies with story progress can be slightly frustrating. The 'dual play' segments—featuring Batman plus another character—were a highlight. I also appreciated using a controller for most gameplay while switching to mouse and keyboard for tank combat. Driving the Batmobile through the city, especially during APC chases, becomes incredibly fun once you master braking to skid around corners. Perfecting this makes navigating the city an absolute delight!

original: Damn fine aaa fps shooter - that's the bottom line. It's looks, sounds and plays great - great fps mechanics, nice story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint hearted though - some of those cutscenes were pretty darn cruel and vivid. But when a game overall is so great, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as i saw 'em: - no sli support - wtf? i had to put the game away until i upgraded my card, as it ran too poorly on my old dual gpu gtx 590. Make sure you have a fairly decent single gpu card. - stupidly small obstacles are often unclimbable.
polished:
Damn fine AAA FPS shooter—that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays brilliantly—stellar mechanics, a gripping story, memorable characters, flawless voice acting, and an epic soundtrack. Not for the faint-hearted, though—some cutscenes are brutally vivid. But when a game excels overall, flaws stand out more. Here’s what I noticed:  
- No SLI support—seriously? I had to shelve it until upgrading my GPU, as performance was abysmal on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. A solid single-GPU card is a must.  
- Some frustratingly small obstacles are inexplicably unclimbable.

original: I'm 2 hours in and am dying from this game. So funny. polished: I’m genuinely sorry, as I try to support free-to-play games and indie developers, but I didn’t enjoy this one. The premise seemed perfect for me, but the execution fell flat. While I love puzzle and exploration games, I found this one unintuitive—even after consulting guides, the gameplay just wasn’t fun. It also lacks a pause button (or if it exists, I couldn’t find it), which feels like a major oversight given the timed sequences. Additionally, the game feels more like a series of cutscenes than actual gameplay, leaving me impatient and disengaged.
