original: Sid meier's civilization beyond earth is a turn-based game in which you build your civilization to a certain goal or 'victory'. In previous games you were set on the earth's timeline going through periods like the stone age, medieval age, and the modern age; however, in this game you are set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What i enjoy about this game is 2k took a new approach to the game and added some new mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. What i didn't enjoy was that with these new mechanics the game could be overwhelming at times. What think could be improved on this game is that they could maybe incorperate some new artwork in the game such as the enviroment you experience when communicating with another leader.
polished: Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game where you develop your civilization toward a specific goal or 'victory.' Unlike previous titles set along Earth's historical timeline—spanning the Stone Age, Medieval era, and Modern Age—this installment takes place in the future as you colonize a new planet. What I appreciate most is 2K's fresh approach, introducing mechanics like the affinity system and orbital layer. However, these additions can occasionally feel overwhelming. One area for improvement could be incorporating new artwork, particularly in environments seen during leader interactions, to enhance immersion.

original: Great game ! tons of replayability and very fun zombie survival game ! def. In my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: after playing 60+ hours i can honestly say this is one of the better more ''realistic'' zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror as you must save up your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when youre infected, etc. Also, i find zombies to feel very natual to be well animated for a free to play game. P.s. : i would recomend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly and you can usually make friends/talk with the people in the chat or over voice comms.
polished: Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience—definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever. Edit: After 60+ hours, I can confidently say this is one of the better, more 'realistic' zombie games. Designed like a survival horror, you must conserve ammo, treat wounds, and manage infections. The zombies feel natural and are well-animated for a free-to-play title. P.S.: I’d recommend playing with 1–2 friends, but the community is super friendly, so you can easily team up or chat via text/voice.

original: 02/07/2014 - it's a shame i can't thoroughly recommend/enjoy this game as from the short time i've played it,i know i'd be addicted if it didn't have the following 2 game breakers. . No aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage,and creates unbearable lag. Mind you,i played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering/lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Couple that with the poor ping,and it just ruins the game. . Everything artifacts like crazy - the menu's,backgrounds,training and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my oc. Set my gpu back to stock and sure enough,it didn't make a difference.
polished:
02/07/2014 - It's disappointing that I can't fully recommend or enjoy this game. From my brief experience, I'd be hooked if not for two major issues:  

1. No Australian servers - A single red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage, causing unbearable lag. Even the offline training mode stuttered (how does that happen?). Combined with poor ping, it ruins the experience.  

2. Constant artifacting - Menus, backgrounds, training, and gameplay all glitch excessively. This has never happened before with my GPU, and resetting to stock settings made no difference.

original: Very late last night i finished this. The story is not very deep or interesting but what makes it stand out is the story-telling. The atmosphere is filled to the brim and the many collectibles do a great job at fleshing it out. I did learn a lot about the world of batman so it was a little disappointing that so few bosses were in the game. Oh well, there's enough future games to rectify that. The combat is the right amount of challenge but it's more on the easy side. Leveling up batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign which add for nice new gameplay mechanics. Getting access to previously unreachable places makes for a nice sense of progression.
polished: Very late last night, I finished this. The story isn’t particularly deep or compelling, but the storytelling elevates it. The atmosphere is immersive, and the collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing out the world. I learned a lot about Batman’s universe, though the lack of bosses was disappointing. Still, future games can address that. Combat strikes a good balance, leaning slightly toward the easier side. Leveling up Batman felt underwhelming, but upgrading and acquiring gadgets introduced engaging new mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable areas created a satisfying sense of progression.

original: 'to the moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think telltale's the walking dead is sad? hohoho! well, it's no match for to the moon! never before have i been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that i did not care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great as well and it definitely does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the doctor who references are endless.
polished: To the Moon" is no mere game—it’s a profound experience, and one of the finest I’ve ever had. Think *The Walking Dead* by Telltale is sad? Well, it pales in comparison to this. Never before has fiction left me so heartbroken yet fulfilled. This masterpiece epitomizes storytelling at its peak, with a soundtrack that’s both charming and flawless. While the controls can be finicky and gameplay isn’t its forte, the narrative is so captivating that it hardly matters. The humor is delightful, never undermining the story’s depth. And the *Doctor Who* references? Endless.

original: Bastion is a bloody brilliant game, with a really great storyline. Set after some calamity happened, you start to rebuild on the bastion. There's quite a lot of choice in the game, with the choice of what to build to give you an advantage, what weapons to use and what power ups to have on those weapons as well as what drinks to use to give you a bonus effect. The art style and music in the game is fantastic, everything looks so colourful at times, who says the apocolypse has to be dull. Best of all, the game has narration based on what you, the player do. So if you end up picking up a weapon then switch it for another in the armoury, the narration would say something of you taking along the new weapon.
polished: Bastion is an outstanding game with a compelling storyline. Set after a catastrophic event, you begin rebuilding the world from the bastion. The game offers abundant choices, from constructing upgrades to selecting weapons, power-ups, and bonus-enhancing drinks. Its art style and music are exceptional, proving that post-apocalyptic settings need not be dreary. The vibrant visuals add depth to the experience. Most impressively, the game features dynamic narration that reacts to your actions. For instance, if you swap weapons in the armory, the narrator comments on your choice, making the gameplay feel uniquely personal. Every decision you make shapes both the world and the story.

original: I had originally bought this game in early development, when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was good. All of the guns at this point were equally overpowered, so there was no problems with imbalance; everyone could kill everyone at any time. Also, the game used to give you unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would think that for a game with 'bajillions of guns', they would at least give you more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before you have to pay to get more. At one point, i had about 3 pages worth of guns, and was planning on new ideas for more, because personally, that's where i found it fun.
polished: I originally purchased this game during its early development, when spacebux was the sole currency and there was no "tech tree." Back then, the game was truly enjoyable. Every gun was equally overpowered, eliminating any balance issues—anyone could defeat anyone at any moment. Additionally, players had unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. For a game boasting "bajillions of guns," you'd expect more than six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring payment for extras. At one point, I owned roughly three pages of guns and was brainstorming new ideas for more—that’s where I found the fun.

original: This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews reflect the fun of this neat little game. It is an odd mix between a classic 2d platformer and an moba, and does it with style. I found myself enjoying characters that i wouldn't enjoy in other moba games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a go anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface is oddly charming. As such, i now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.
polished: This game was a delightful surprise. While rave reviews can often be misleading, here they perfectly capture the fun of this charming little title. It blends a classic 2D platformer with MOBA elements seamlessly and stylishly. I unexpectedly enjoyed characters I'd typically avoid in other MOBAs. Though skeptical, I tried a melee tank and was pleasantly surprised—leading me to experiment with more as they unlocked. The art style and interface have a quirky appeal. I now use one character as my avatar and even a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.

original: I just started playing, but i love this game. I put on my headphone and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been awhile since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are right on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubt about the navel combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! the only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming just get outta there, regroup, and counter-assault. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!
polished: I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in it for hours. It's been a while since a game captivated me like this. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. Every combat encounter excites me, and the system is brilliantly optimized. I had doubts about the naval combat, but destroying multiple fleets is incredibly fun! The only way to lose is failing to retreat. If combat seems overwhelming, just retreat, regroup, and strike back. Thanks, devs, for an amazing experience!

original: The reboot of the devil may cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for series’ protagonist, dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it’s certainly for the better; and this new game by ninja theory proves it. Dmc serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear, narrative arc for the new dante, making him a compelling character to watch.image the story follows dante as he’s introduced into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.
polished: The reboot of the *Devil May Cry* franchise has introduced significant changes to the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. While longtime fans may initially resist these alterations, the new direction ultimately benefits the character—a fact *Ninja Theory*’s latest installment convincingly demonstrates. *DmC* serves as an ideal entry point for newcomers, tracing the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and charting his transformation into selflessness. The game crafts a clear, engaging narrative arc for this reimagined hero, making his journey compelling to witness. The story follows Dante as he confronts the corrupt world he once willfully ignored.

original: Where do i start on this absolutely beautiful game. It's story, is absolutely charming. It has so much detail put into it, and it is a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, secrets. It is serious when it needs to be, but isn't a stranger to funny moments. The character design is on point, with there being various characters with various personailities and secrets to them. It sticks out from other rpg's because you don't have to kill anyone, which is an unused concept in rpg's. With lots of inspiration from earthbound, one of the best rpg's i have seen, you can tell that it is going to be good. It easily has the best soundtrack i've heard in forever.
polished: Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, packed with detail, and brimming with happiness—bad puns, mischievous dogs, and hidden secrets included. It balances seriousness with humor effortlessly. The character design shines, featuring diverse personalities and intriguing backstories. What sets it apart from other RPGs is the option to complete it without killing anyone—a rare and refreshing concept. Drawing inspiration from *EarthBound*, one of the finest RPGs, it’s clear this game is something special. Plus, its soundtrack is the best I’ve heard in years.

original: I am recommending this solely because it's free, and might be a more 'enjoyable' experience for others. As for my experience, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor. I was not shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Maybe i'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to warrant a reaction out of me. As for the other half of the game, it tries to paint a picture (literally) of a person in mental decline. It deals with obsession, hallucination, depression and a few other things. In theory it is a cool idea. But the 'game' took me 10 minutes to complete, and that is with reading and taking in every little bit of information i could.
polished: I recommend this solely because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. Personally, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock value, but I felt neither shocked nor emotionally moved. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simplistic to elicit a reaction. The other half attempts to depict mental decline through themes of obsession, hallucination, and depression. While the concept is intriguing in theory, the execution fell short. The entire 'game' took me just 10 minutes to complete, even while carefully reading and absorbing every detail.

original: Do i even need to explain why portal is amazing? portal is a puzzle game, it gives you a concept then gets out. It is an amazing way to test your mind while still being fun. Although this game isn't as story heavy, it did give birth to one of the most good popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when i am feeling bored and i love to come back and to see what gave birth to a legend and what is a legend. Gameplay: portal's gameplay is quite simple, to explain at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two buttons are in the game, one that you press and one that you need a cube to put on.
polished:
Do I even need to explain why *Portal* is amazing? It's a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps back, offering a brilliant way to challenge your mind while remaining fun. Though not heavily story-driven, it spawned one of the most beloved games of 2011. I still revisit and complete it when bored, marveling at what birthed a legend—and what *is* a legend.  

**Gameplay:** *Portal*'s mechanics are simple to explain. You use portals strategically, alongside buttons that activate puzzle elements. There are two button types: one you press and another requiring a cube.

original: If you can overlook the bugs (which i personally only had two: one minor and the other quite annoying) edit: both bugs are resolved one fix increased my fps from 60-90 to 80-120 and are looking for a space exploration game, i can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews are about specs, i'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€) radeon rx480 (~200€) z170 pro - gaming (~150€) 16gb ddr4 ram (~70€) ~650€ is definitely within the medium price range though, granted, this rig is quite new. Almost constant 60+ fps on high settings vsync enabled i genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they're rocking an overkill setup and get 20fps.
polished: If you can overlook the bugs (I personally encountered only two—one minor and the other quite annoying—both now resolved, with one fix boosting my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120) and are seeking a space exploration game, I highly recommend this. Since most reviews focus on specs, here are mine: i5 6600k (~€200), Radeon RX 480 (~€200), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~€150), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~€70). At ~€650, this rig falls within the mid-range price bracket, though it’s relatively new. I maintain nearly constant 60+ FPS on high settings with V-Sync enabled. I’m baffled by claims of overkill setups yielding 20 FPS.

original: Remember age of mythology? yeah, it's been that long since there's been an rts game of such quality. Divinity: dragon commander reaches awfully close to these borders of my personal most favourite rts game. Combine this with a huge risk-like grand strategy mode and there, it hit the spot. I am not (read: try not to be) overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking and even commanding unit production, direction and spawning at the very same time. Honestly, i do like the complicated rts games nowadays. Think of civ v and so on. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts and resources all into one complicated game mode.
polished:
Remember *Age of Mythology*? It’s been ages since we’ve seen an RTS of that caliber. *Divinity: Dragon Commander* comes remarkably close to being my personal favorite. Pair that with a grand strategy mode reminiscent of *Risk*, and it truly delivers. I won’t deny my bias—being able to transform into a dragon, supporting troops, attacking, and managing unit production simultaneously is incredible.  

These days, I appreciate complex RTS games like *Civ V*. Yet, many try to cram intricate mechanics, charts, and resources into a single overwhelming experience.

original: Undertale comes together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is nice, but paired together they make some truly beautiful and impacting moments. The script runs the gammut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and does this while turning rpg tropes on their head. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, i'll just say this: if you like rpgs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.
polished: Undertale combines its elements to create something extraordinary. The retro-style graphics and soundtrack are strong on their own, but together they craft breathtaking, emotional moments. The writing seamlessly shifts from hilarious to tragic to uplifting—often simultaneously—while cleverly subverting RPG conventions. This doesn’t even cover the world, characters, story, or gameplay, each deserving essays of praise. Instead, I’ll keep it simple: if you enjoy RPGs, play this game. If you love video games, play this game. If you have seven spare hours in your lifetime, play this game.

original: If you liked witcher 1 and 2, witcher 3 is must to get. I would give normally for this game 10/10 but unfortunatly after 1.03 this game turned into buggy ♥♥♥♥ + random crashes, so remember to save really often. When i played version 1.00 -> 1.03 my game never crashed, i didnt see any bugs. Also i have noticed that after 1.03 patch drawing distance sometimes is horrible, starting to draw objects when youre really close, sometimes even people. But if forgetting all these bugs, crashes and drawdistance 'bugs', this is really fantastic game, they made huge effort on quests, some of them really emotional and deep, lots of side quests, and the fact that your decision effects a lot in this game. I have played over 50 hours now and still going on.
polished:
If you enjoyed *The Witcher 1* and *2*, *The Witcher 3* is a must-play. I’d typically rate this game 10/10, but unfortunately, after patch 1.03, it became buggy with random crashes—so save often. Between versions 1.00 and 1.03, my game never crashed, and I encountered no bugs. Post-1.03, draw distance suffers, with objects—and even people—sometimes appearing only when close.  

Ignoring these issues, the game is fantastic. The developers poured immense effort into quests, many of which are emotional and deep, alongside countless side quests. Your choices significantly impact the world. I’ve played over 50 hours and still can’t put it down.

original: I have only had this game for a few months, but in just that short amount of time, two dlc's have come out, along with patches that have made an already great game into an excellent one. The devs are very active in the community, and it really shows in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics of which i am still trying to learn; however, this breadth of strategy allows you a myriad of ways to reach goals and take advantage of certain situations. The game, in my mind, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself sucked into every session i play regardless of how the play-through is going.
polished: I’ve only had this game for a few months, yet in that short time, two DLCs have been released alongside patches that transformed an already great game into an exceptional one. The developers are highly engaged with the community, evident in forums and dev diaries. Though the mechanics have a steep learning curve—I’m still mastering them—the depth of strategy offers countless ways to achieve goals and capitalize on situations. To me, the game feels nearly infinitely replayable. Every session draws me in, no matter how the playthrough unfolds.

original: Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those few enjoyable hours you'll begin to see that the only thing left the game has to offer is repetition in it's combat, enemies and game play. The one major high point for the game is that the developers are working hard and do semi-frequent updates that generally include a lot of content from sweeping changes to some of the game's systems, new warframes and other tweaks/features. It's a good game to play casually. Though i doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you just really like grinding. The upside to all of this is that the game is free so i'd recommend trying it out. If you're looking for a quick fix, try it out.
polished: Warframe is an enjoyable game for the first few hours. After that initial thrill, however, you’ll notice the combat, enemies, and gameplay become repetitive. The standout feature is the developers’ dedication, with semi-frequent updates that introduce sweeping changes, new Warframes, and other tweaks. It’s a solid casual experience, though unlikely to hold your interest beyond a few months unless you love grinding. The best part? It’s free, so it’s worth a try. If you’re after a quick gaming fix, give it a shot.

original: This game is so.. Very.. Boring. I bought this game because i believed it was a pc version of 'katamari damacy', a popular and nice ps 2 game. Sadly it's far from it. In this game you go about, absorbing ever bigger things to grow bigger and absorb bigger things. But the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels not inventive and what is in it is a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show but, one that makes you rather depressed and rethink whether being alive is all it should be. Every 'living' creature in this game from small pets to human beings makes me wonder if the creators of this game had an interest in taxidermy.
polished: This game is incredibly dull. I purchased it believing it was a PC version of *Katamari Damacy*, a beloved PS2 title. Unfortunately, it falls far short. The gameplay involves absorbing progressively larger objects to grow bigger, but the mechanics are clunky, the levels uninspired, and the overall experience feels like a surreal horror show—not the entertaining kind, but one that leaves you questioning existence. Every "living" creature, from pets to humans, makes me wonder if the developers had a fascination with taxidermy.

original: Alright. Let me explain a few things, as a person very intrested in politics, i was very interested in this game when i first heard about it. I thought, 'oh wow! a simulator of the road to becoming president! that sounds fun!' well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off and says you need to pick a side: republican or democrat, there is no independent, or third party. A little dissapointed, but still optimistic, i carried on to see what i could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to mess around with. It's the only time its an option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.
polished: Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone very interested in politics, I was excited when I first heard about this game. I thought, *Wow! A simulator about becoming president—that sounds fun!* Well, it wasn’t. The game forces you to pick a side: Republican or Democrat, with no independent or third-party option. A little disappointed but still hopeful, I continued to explore. I’ll give the game credit—the character customization, though limited, is fun to experiment with. It’s the only time you can choose whether to wear your head in a campaign. Literally.

original: Fallout 3 story was better. Settlements get in the way of the story to the point you'll hate baby sitting them instead of playing the story. Some keys are hard coded and cannot be rebound. Bugs galore. My pipboy disappeared permanently at one point and had to research console commands to get it back. You don't have to work for power armor it's basically given to you from the beginning of the game and power cores are everywhere in trader shops. Value of power armor diminished greatly from previous fallout games. Story is medicore, everything about this game is mediocre except it doesn't crash every 10 mins like fallout 3. Very stable compared to fallout 3. Is it better than fallout 3 no. Is it better than new vegas? no. This title was so overhyped for how bad it actually is.
polished: Fallout 3’s story was superior. Settlements disrupt the narrative, making you resent babysitting them instead of progressing. Some keys are hardcoded and unchangeable. Bugs are rampant—my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, forcing me to use console commands. Power armor lacks effort; it’s handed to you early, and fusion cores are overly abundant, diminishing its value compared to past games. The story is mediocre, as is most of the game, though it’s more stable than Fallout 3’s frequent crashes. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. New Vegas? No. This title was vastly overhyped for its disappointing quality.

original: My stats (at the time of writing this review): - 8.6 hrs to get to the end - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - zero achievements out of 15 what i liked: - visuals up until the last level (ice caves) - story is not that great, but the ending (after the closing credits) kind of made me not regret so much spending my time playing this game what i disliked: - visuals in the last level are uninteresting - gameplay in the last level gets much harder making it become a frustrating experience of having to do a lot of things over and over again until you get it right - achievements are too hard. There are 13 (out of 15) that only less than 2,1% of players achieved!
polished:
Here’s the polished version:  

"My stats (at the time of writing this review):  
- 8.6 hours to complete  
- 10/25 collectibles found  
- 0/15 achievements unlocked  

What I liked:  
- Visuals (except for the last level, Ice Caves)  
- The story isn’t great, but the post-credits ending made the playtime feel worthwhile  

What I disliked:  
- The last level’s visuals were dull  
- Gameplay there became frustratingly difficult, forcing repetitive retries  
- Achievements are overly hard—13/15 have less than a 2.1% completion rate!

original: Pros: +graphic cons: -bugs(especially the environment, you may get stuck or your shots may hit a invisible wall despite having clear line of sight of the enemy) -game is handholding/ babysitting you -dumb ai -enemies always seem to know where you are when you are spotted -godlike accuracy by the enemy which is frustrating like the first ghost warrior. -terrible checkpoints and saves. -boring story that i couldn't care less about will not recommend it unless its 90% off even then i find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing for the sake of finishing it to move unto the next game in my library. Considering the time i wasted on the first ghost warrior (which was equally boring and i feel liberated when i finished it), i probably won't play it until the end.
polished:
Pros:  
+ Great graphics  

Cons:  
- Bugs, especially in the environment (e.g., getting stuck or shots hitting invisible walls despite clear line of sight)  
- Excessive handholding  
- Dumb AI  
- Enemies always pinpoint your location once spotted  
- Frustratingly godlike enemy accuracy, reminiscent of the first Ghost Warrior  
- Poor checkpoint and save system  
- Unengaging story that fails to hold interest  

Verdict:  
Not recommended unless it’s 90% off—even then, it feels like a tedious chore. I’m only playing to finish it and move on. Given how dull the first Ghost Warrior was (and the relief I felt upon completing it), I doubt I’ll see this one through.

original: Review for 29/11/2015 do not buy this game, servers offline. You can't play. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. While i could play it, i enjoyed it. original: Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :d this puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large branching map. This game is quite amusing and running through it to complete the game was quite a bit of fun. ^_^ it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements though. To get all the cubes you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher. These can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking into a guide (*raises hand* i gave up. -_-). The guide, 'a complete guide to fez!!!'
polished: Who wouldn’t want to wear a fez? :d This charming puzzle-platformer stars a fez-wearing hero who collects fragments to form cubes while exploring a vast, branching world. The game is delightful, and completing it is genuinely enjoyable. ^_^ However, collecting all cubes and achievements can be mildly frustrating. Unlocking them requires deciphering codes, which may take moments or push you to consult a guide (*raises hand*—I gave up. -_-). The guide, "A Complete Guide to FEZ!!!

original: It's not hard for me to see why other people like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing i have a vive and i'm much more interested in playing room sized games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe inspiring in the scale of its universe, but i also felt that same scale was a hinderence to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too large for me. Perhaps if i were more patient and had more time for gaming this would be compelling to me. But i don't have either and there are plenty more vr games i'd rather spend my time on.
polished: It's not hard for me to understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I own a Vive and prefer playing room-scale games with motion controllers. Additionally, while the game's vast universe is initially awe-inspiring, I found that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and the time required to do anything engaging early on were both excessive for me. Perhaps with more patience and gaming time, I’d find it compelling. But I lack both, and there are plenty of other VR games I'd rather play.

original: Hands down my favorite first person shooter of all time. Run and gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload half-way through your magazine all the time then you will have a pouch full of half full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you have caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.
polished: Undoubtedly my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun Rambo tactics won’t work here. Recoil and ballistics feel authentic—rifle rounds to the chest, neck, or head are almost always lethal unless they barely graze you. Bullets drop over distance, and controlled bursts are essential for accuracy. No unlimited ammo here: reload mid-magazine too often, and you’ll end up with pouches full of half-empty clips. Sprinting exhausts you, impairing aim until you catch your breath. Stabilize your weapon by resting it on your elbows when prone or on a ledge. Standing reduces accuracy.

original: Let me start off by saying i did not purchase eu when it first came out and that i got it on sale which included ew so i never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game however, it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for xcom2 i love it, the game plays pretty well for me on medium and i am running a gtx560 with 2gb of vram. At first the game set it to high and it was running a bit sluggishly but not to the point of being unplayable but when i dropped it down to medium it smoothed on out. Not sure if i am just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they are coming from some really entitled people.
polished:
Let me start by saying I didn’t purchase EU when it first released—I got it on sale with EW included, so I never experienced the issues some claim to have had. That said, I loved the game. It was unforgiving early on but rewarding when executed well.  

As for XCOM 2, I adore it. The game runs smoothly on medium settings with my GTX 560 (2GB VRAM). Initially, it defaulted to high and ran sluggishly, though not unplayably so. Dropping to medium fixed it.  

I’m not sure if I’m just lucky with game issues, but many negative reviews seem to come from overly entitled players.

original: World leaders gather to face uncertainty more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the swiss mountain resort davos for the annual world economic forum (wef). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from china's economic power to iraq's future after this sunday's elections. Uk prime minister tony blair and south african president thabo mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the wef are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The brazilian city of porto alegre will host the rival world social forum, timed to run in parallel with the wef's ritzier event in davos.
polished: World leaders gather to face uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political figures converge on the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will address pressing issues, from China's economic influence to Iraq's post-election future. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the 20+ heads of state attending. Unlike past years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued, with anti-globalization activists canceling a planned weekend demonstration. Meanwhile, Porto Alegre, Brazil, will host the rival World Social Forum, scheduled to coincide with Davos' high-profile event.

original: Deadline nears for fiat-gm deal fiat and general motors (gm) have until midnight on 1 february to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to gm, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. Gm, whose own european operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent fiat shares down 1.2% on tuesday, after monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The us firm is thought to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by fiat's decision to sell off fiat's finance arm and halve gm's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between gm and daimlerchrysler to ally with fiat.
polished:
**Polished text:**  

The deadline for the Fiat-GM deal is approaching, with Fiat and General Motors (GM) having until midnight on 1 February to resolve their dispute over a potential takeover. By this deadline, Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, as stipulated in their 2000 alliance agreement. GM, struggling with losses in its European operations, no longer wishes to acquire Fiat’s unprofitable unit. Reports of stalled negotiations caused Fiat shares to drop 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% rise on Monday amid hopes of a settlement. GM is reportedly offering around $2bn (£1.06bn) to exit the agreement, claiming it was invalidated when Fiat sold its finance arm and diluted GM’s stake through a capital increase. The original deal emerged from a competition between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

original: Cardinal criticises iraq war cost billions of pounds spent on conflict in iraq and in the middle east should have been used to reduce poverty, cardinal cormac murphy-o'connor has said. The head of the catholic church in england and wales made the comments on bbc radio 4 and will re-iterate his stance in his christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a christmas message to denounce the war in iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the archbishop of canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on bbc radio 4's thought for the day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history poverty".
polished: Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, has criticised the Iraq War, stating that billions spent on conflicts in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to alleviate poverty. He made these remarks on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance during his Christmas Midnight Mass. In his Christmas message, the cardinal denounced the war as a "terrible" waste of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have voiced opposition to the conflict. Speaking on BBC Radio 4’s *Thought for the Day*, he lamented that "billions" were spent on war rather than lifting people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The cardinal urged that 2005 become the year to campaign and "make poverty history.

original: British stars denied major oscars british hopes of winning major oscars were dashed as uk stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, mike leigh's vera drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards and there was no prize for star imelda staunton. Kate winslet also lost to best actress hilary swank, while clive owen and sophie okonedo failed to win best supporting actor awards. The uk's andrea arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows number 73 and motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow uk nominees gary mckendry and ashvin kumar.
polished: British stars were denied major Oscars as UK hopes of winning top awards were dashed. Kate Winslet lost the Best Actress category to Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo were overlooked for supporting actor awards. Arnold, a former children’s TV presenter in the 1980s, called the win "totally overwhelming." *Wasp* follows a struggling single mother, triumphing over films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

original: Halloween writer debra hill dies screenwriter and producer debra hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic halloween, has died in los angeles aged 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred jamie lee curtis as a babysitter terrorised by a psychopath. Directed by john carpenter, it made over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with carpenter on escape from new york and the fog. Born in new jersey, hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly taken by men.
polished: Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for co-writing the 1970s horror classic *Halloween*, has died in Los Angeles at age 54 after battling cancer. Hill collaborated with director John Carpenter on the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter hunted by a masked killer. The movie grossed over $60 million worldwide—a record for independent cinema at the time. She also partnered with Carpenter on *Escape from New York* and *The Fog*. Born in New Jersey, Hill started as a production assistant and rose through the ranks, becoming an assistant and second-unit director before her creative partnership with Carpenter. A trailblazer for women in film, she took on roles in the 70s typically dominated by men.

original: Broadband fuels online expression fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by uk think-tank demos. It said that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the uk have broadband and that number is growing fast. The demos report looked at the impact of broadband on people's net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.
polished: Broadband fuels online expression, as fast web access encourages more people to share their thoughts digitally, research suggests. A quarter of UK broadband users regularly upload content or maintain personal sites, according to a report by think-tank Demos. Fast, always-on connections are transforming internet usage, it notes. Over five million UK households now have broadband, with adoption rapidly increasing. The study examined broadband's impact on online behavior, revealing that more than half of users log on before breakfast. One in five even admitted to waking at night to browse. Most notably, the report argues broadband is fostering greater online participation.

original: Yukos heading back to us courts russian oil and gas company yukos is due in a us court on thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by russian authorities in order to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the us, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, yuganskneftegas. The unit was however sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated us bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.
polished: Yukos is set to appear in a U.S. court on Thursday as it battles for survival. The Russian oil and gas company is being dismantled by authorities to settle a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for U.S. bankruptcy, aiming to leverage international business law to stop the forced sale of its key unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was sold for $9.4bn to state-owned Rosneft after the auction faced disruptions. Yukos lawyers argue the sale violated U.S. bankruptcy law. The company and its major shareholders have pledged to pursue legal action against any buyer of its assets, using all available means.

original: Voters flock to blog awards site voting is under way for the annual bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top us dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to us research think-tank pew internet and american life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

original: Chinese dam firm 'defies beijing' the china three gorges project corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the chinese state press has said. The builder of the three gorges dam is continuing work on the sister xiluodu dam, said the beijing news. The xiluodu dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction projects called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The beijing news said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the three gorges underground power plant and the three gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by china's state environmental protection agency (sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.
polished: Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing'—China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, according to state media. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam persists in work on the Xiluodu Dam, reported *Beijing News*. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale projects suspended due to insufficient environmental reviews. *Beijing News* noted the company may opt to pay a fine instead. The firm has also disregarded orders to stop work at two other sites—the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Power Supply Plant. To date, only 22 of the 30 projects flagged by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for lacking mandatory environmental assessments have adhered to the shutdown directive.

original: Man city 0-2 man utd manchester united reduced chelsea's premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over manchester city. Wayne rooney met gary neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off richard dunne, to put united ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate dunne hooked a volley over david james' head and into his own net. Steve mcmanaman wasted city's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes united had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a paul scholes header over the bar.
polished:
Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a hard-fought 2-0 win over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney capitalized on Gary Neville's cross, firing a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne to give United the lead. Seven minutes later, Dunne's misfortune continued as he volleyed the ball over David James and into his own net. City squandered their best opportunity when Steve McManaman shot wide from close range in the first half.  

United initially struggled to assert dominance, their play more sluggish than measured, creating only one clear chance—a Paul Scholes header over the bar. Despite this, they secured the crucial victory to stay in the title race.

original: Wales 'must learn health lessons' the new health minister for wales says there are lessons to learn from england in tackling waiting lists. Dr brian gibbons, on his first full day in the job after jane hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. But both plaid cymru and the liberal democrats said dr gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile ms hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda. Dr gibbons, who was a gp in blaengwynfi, in the upper afan valley, before becoming am for aberavon, said nhs staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". One of the biggest problems which had faced ms hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in wales.
polished: Wales 'must learn health lessons,' says the new health minister, Dr. Brian Gibbons, who highlights the need to address waiting lists by learning from England's approach. Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, however, urged policy changes. Ms. Hutt defended her tenure, stating waiting times represented "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi before becoming AM for Aberavon, noted NHS staff sought stability after "tremendous change and reform." Ms. Hutt's five-and-a-half-year term as Wales' first health minister was notably challenged by lengthy waiting lists.

original: Ferguson hails man utd's resolve manchester united's alex ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at aston villa. polished:
Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve  
Manchester United's Alex Ferguson praised his players' resilient performance in their 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game this season—a fantastic, end-to-end match with excellent passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We displayed tremendous character and determination. I knew we wouldn’t lose.  

"Looking at this fixture, we’ve already won here, while Arsenal and Chelsea still have to visit, and Villa might be stronger by then." Ferguson also lauded veterans Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who replaced the injured John O’Shea. "Roy brought much-needed composure to midfield—a quality no one else possesses.

original: Singer's film to show at festival a documentary which takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer george michael will be shown at this year's berlin film festival. A different story will screen in the panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 february. It features the singer talking about both his career and his personal life, from his days in wham! through to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 february. Director southan morris and executive producer andy stephens will also attend the festival. The 93 minute film will see michael discussing his early days in wham! along with his later career, including his legal battles with record label sony and his stance against the iraq war and american politics.
polished: A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. *A Different Story* will screen in the festival's Panorama section, running from 10–20 February. The film explores Michael's career and personal journey, from his Wham! days to recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February, joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute documentary delves into his early years with Wham!, his solo career, legal disputes with Sony Records, and his opposition to the Iraq War and American politics.

original: Downloads enter us singles chart digital music downloads are being included in the main us singles chart for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green day's boulevard of broken dreams is currently number two in billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the uk singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the us are already used to compile billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to us radio stations which play chart music.
polished: Digital music downloads are now included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart integrates download sales data, previously limited to a separate chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" ranks second on Billboard's Pop chart and leads its digital chart. The UK singles chart will also incorporate download sales later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. These will now be combined with physical singles and airplay data for the updated Hot 100. A second new chart, the Pop 100, merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but restricts airplay data to US radio stations playing chart music.

original: Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard the net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott richter, the man behind optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into chapter 11. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems but still keep trading. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog spamhaus, optinrealbig was sued in december 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by microsoft and new york attorney general eliot spitzer who alleged that mr richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.
polished: Anti-spam laws hit the net's self-proclaimed "spam king" hard, forcing him to seek bankruptcy protection. Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer accused Richter and associates of sending billions of spam messages through 514 hijacked IPs across 35 countries.

original: Arnesen denies rift with santini tottenham sporting director frank arnesen has denied that coach jacques santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at white hart lane. There had been newspaper speculation that santini had felt undermined by arnesen's role at the club. "it is absolutely not true," arnesen told bbc radio five live. "there is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. original: Ireland surge past scots ireland maintained their six nations grand slam ambitions with an impressive victory over scotland at murrayfield. Hugo southwell's try gave the scots an early 8-0 lead but scores from locks malcolm o'kelly and paul o'connell put the visitors in command by half-time. After two hard-earned away victories, eddie o'sullivan' side can now look forward to welcoming england to lansdowne road in a fortnight. original: Robinson wants dual code success england rugby union captain jason robinson has targeted dual code success over australia on saturday. original: Sun offers processing by the hour sun microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service which will allow customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company which believes that computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said sun's chief operating officer jonathan schwartz. "why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked in a webcast launching sun's quarterly network computing event in california.

Walmart initiated the effort with ads in publications like *The Wall Street Journal*, featuring an open letter from CEO Lee Scott. He stated it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth," adding, "Many 'urban myths' circulate about Walmart, but facts remain facts.

original: Tories outlining policing plans local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. Party leader michael howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He said the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The lib dems said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while labour criticised "extravagant" tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the police federation of england and wales, which represents rank and file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained. Jan berry said: "it is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. "these plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned.
polished: The Conservatives have unveiled plans for local communities to elect their own police commissioners. Party leader Michael Howard stated this new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities but wouldn’t override chief constables. The Lib Dems warned the proposal could empower extreme groups, while Labour criticized "extravagant" Tory policing promises. Responding, Jan Berry, chair of the Police Federation of England and Wales, stressed the need to retain operational independence. "Policing is a service, not a political football to be kicked around during elections," she said. Berry also cautioned that the plans risked letting extreme political views dictate on-the-ground operations.

original: At a glance: tory health checks the uk' opposition conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: people coming to live and work in britain from outside the eu. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with lots of tb, they would have to have a chest x-ray and further tests if appropriate. All people from outside the european union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical. Tuberculosis, hepatitis b and hiv. A positive test for tb would automatically mean visa applications being turned down. All other conditions would be dealt with on a case by case basis.
polished: At a glance: The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here’s a breakdown of the proposal: Individuals moving to Britain from outside the EU who intend to stay six months or more—and are from high-TB countries—would require a chest X-ray and further tests if necessary. Those from outside the European Union planning to stay a year or longer must undergo a full medical examination, screening for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would result in automatic visa rejection, while other conditions would be assessed case by case.

original: Paris promise raises welsh hopes has there been a better six nations match than saturday's epic in paris? and can the welsh revival continue all the way to a first grand slam since 1978? those are the two questions occupying not just wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in paris. Welsh legend mervyn davies, a member of two of three grand slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn williams, wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games i have ever played in". A crestfallen france coach, bernard laporte, simply observed: "there was a french half and there was a welsh half".
polished: Paris Promise Raises Welsh Hopes. Has there ever been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can Wales' revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? These questions are on the minds of not just Welsh supporters but rugby fans everywhere after a scintillating display. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, part of two Grand Slam-winning sides in the 1970s, called it "one of the great performances of the past 30 years." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer, described it as "one of the most surreal games I've ever played in." A dejected France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply noted: "There was a French half and a Welsh half."

original: Doves soar to uk album summit manchester rock band doves have entered the uk album chart at number one with their new release, some cities. The trio replace flamboyant us act scissor sisters at the top. The album follows single black and white town, which reached number six. R&b star nelly has the new number one single with over and over, which sees him team up with tim mcgraw. Girls aloud, akon and kaiser chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, as do futureheads and usher. The latest elvis presley re-release, (marie's the name) his latest flame, entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of girls aloud's wake me up. Hip-hop performer akon's locked up is at number five, while hotly-tipped leeds band kaiser chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with oh my god.
polished:
Manchester rock band Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their new release, *Some Cities*. The trio replaces flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at number one. Their album follows the single *Black and White Town*, which peaked at number six.  

R&B star Nelly claims the new number one single with *Over and Over*, featuring Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs also have new singles in the top ten, alongside Futureheads and Usher.  

Elvis Presley’s re-release, *(Marie’s the Name) His Latest Flame*, enters at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud’s *Wake Me Up*. Akon’s *Locked Up* sits at five, while Kaiser Chiefs’ *Oh My God* lands at six.

original: Davies favours gloucester future wales hooker mefin davies is likely to stay with english side gloucester despite reported interest from the neath-swansea ospreys. Bbc wales understands the ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but that he would prefer to stay where he is. Davies, one of the stars of saturday's rbs six nations win over england, is only on a year contract at kingsholm. But the hooker has proved his worth to the zurich premiership side and is likely to get a new deal next season. The summer demise of the celtic warriors region left davies in the cold and forced him to take a semi-professional contract with neath rfc. Although he got match time with the ospreys at the request of the wales management, he admitted before his move to gloucester that he was angry with the way he was treated.
polished:
Davies favors Gloucester future  
Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to remain with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old, but he prefers to stay put.  

Davies, a standout in Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proven his value to the Zurich Premiership side and is expected to secure a new deal next season.  

The Celtic Warriors' collapse left Davies sidelined, forcing him to accept a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Though he played for the Ospreys at Wales' request, he admitted frustration over his treatment before joining Gloucester.

original: Cabinet anger at brown cash raid ministers are unhappy about plans to use whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government minister nick raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on thursday. Mr raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. But he said local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in england keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr raynsford said nearly all central government departments had an interest in well run local authorities.
polished:
Cabinet Anger at Brown Cash Raid  

Ministers are displeased with plans to use Whitehall funds to curb council tax hikes, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has admitted. Chancellor Gordon Brown redirected £512m from central to local budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday.  

Raynsford revealed holding "frank discussions" with colleagues over the move but stressed that councils must maintain quality services without steep tax increases. The central funds form part of a £1bn package to help English local authorities limit next year’s council tax rises below 5%—a likely election year.  

Raynsford noted that nearly all central departments have a stake in well-managed local governments.

original: Israeli club look to africa four african players, including zimbabwe goalkeeper energy murambadoro, are all ready to play for israeli club hapoel bnei sakhnin in the uefa cup. Bnei sakhnin are the first arab side ever to play in european competition and will play english premiership side newcastle united in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper murambadoro, who made a name for himself at the african nations cup finals in tunisia, helped bnei sakhnin overcome albania's partizani tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro moved to israel recently after a brief stint with south african club hellenic. The club won the israeli cup final last season and are based in sakhnin, which is near haifa. The club have a strong ethic and are high profile promoters of peace and co-operation within israel.
polished: An Israeli club is turning to Africa, with four African players—including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro—set to feature for Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin, the first Arab team to compete in European football, will face English Premier League side Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who rose to prominence during the Africa Cup of Nations in Tunisia, played a key role in their 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. After a short spell with South African club Hellenic, he recently joined the Israeli side. Based near Haifa in Sakhnin, the club won last season's Israeli Cup and is renowned for its strong ethics and commitment to promoting peace and cooperation in Israel.

original: New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University college london research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety as mps are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert professor richard allsop, says cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the uk's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 department of transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.
polished:
A new report suggests that reducing drink-drive limits by a third could save more lives than previously estimated. Research from University College London indicates that lowering the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would prevent 65 deaths annually. The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, coincide with MPs voting on the government’s Road Safety Bill, which addresses speeding fines but not drink-drive limits.  

Transport expert Professor Richard Allsop’s study also predicts 230 fewer serious road injuries compared to 2003, saving the UK £119m yearly. A 1998 Department of Transport estimate had projected only 50 lives saved annually with such a change.

original: This paper presents a millimeter-scale cmos 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This obviates the need for using power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype asic is fabricated in tsmc 65 nm lp cmos process and consumes the average static power of 0.535 mw under 1.2 v analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 mev proton beam setting.
polished: This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single particle in the depletion region, while the array offers a 512×512 μm² detection area. Rather than sensing voltage drop from radiation, the system measures pulse width—the time for voltage to return to baseline—eliminating the need for power-hungry ADCs. A prototype ASIC, fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS, consumes 0.535 mW static power at 1.2 V supply. The system is successfully validated in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam.

original: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (avs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that avs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize avs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (so) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (ue) seeking avs and human-driven vehicles (hvs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering mixed fleet of avs and hvs.
polished: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to mitigate the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, assuming AVs would readily accept external control by a central authority is unrealistic. This paper proposes a joint routing and pricing control scheme to incentivize AVs toward centrally optimized routing by offering toll savings, while user-equilibrium-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) face congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization: dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, while the lower level employs a simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model for mixed AV-HV fleets.

original: Optomechanics and electromechanics have made it possible to prepare macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. In addition to coaxing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has encouraged ideas of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. But the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility to escape this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.
polished: Optomechanics and electromechanics now enable macroscopic mechanical oscillators to be prepared in quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. Beyond pushing larger objects into the quantum regime, this capability has spurred ideas for using mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing, communication, and as ultra-precise force sensors surpassing the standard quantum limit. However, the predominantly linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to richer quantum states, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early proposals suggested overcoming this limitation through strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. While experiments have demonstrated quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, nonclassical states of motion remain elusive.

original: Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make decisions. Unfortunately, the evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have learned increasingly insidious and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to the deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are hard to capture, as they can be varying quickly along time, different across spammers and target products, and more critically, remained unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not well-aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address the challenges, we formulate a minimax game where the spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical goals that are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.
polished: Online reviews offer valuable product evaluations to guide customer decisions. However, these assessments can be distorted by fake reviews ("spams") from professional spammers, who continually refine deceptive strategies to evade detection. Spamming tactics are difficult to track, as they evolve rapidly over time, vary among spammers and target products, and often remain undiscovered. Moreover, most existing detectors prioritize accuracy, which does not fully align with preserving evaluation trustworthiness. To tackle these challenges, we propose a minimax game where spammers and detectors compete based on practical objectives beyond mere detection accuracy. Nash equilibria in this game yield robust detectors resilient to mixed spamming strategies.

original: We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we use the lewis-riesenfeld (l-r) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the l-r invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.
polished: We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high-fidelity population transfer in a 3-level quantum system with lambda configuration. To achieve high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions enabling exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Within this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to simultaneously control transfer fidelity, excited-state population, and robustness. We quantify robustness as the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas at which infidelity exceeds $10^{-4}$. Our shaped pulses demonstrate superior robustness compared to Gaussian and adiabatically optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.
