His chisel was his sole tool. Yet life isn’t carved—it grows. Within our cells, the smallest units of life, lies all the information needed for function and replication. Tools shape outcomes. Since the Industrial Revolution, design has been governed by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

original: Hello. My name is simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous when onstage, picture people in the audience naked? like it's this thing that's supposed to make you feel better. But i was thinking — picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. Like, we're working really hard on moving past stuff like that, so we need a new method of dealing with if you get nervous onstage. And i realized that what i'd really like is that i can look at you as much as you're looking at me — just to even things out a little bit. So if i had way more eyeballs, then we'd all be really comfortable, right?
polished: Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people say if you get nervous onstage, picture the audience naked? It’s supposed to help, but imagining all of you naked in 2018 feels strange and outdated. We’re working hard to move past that, so we need a better way to handle stage fright. I realized what would really help is if I could look at you as much as you look at me—just to balance things out. So if I had way more eyeballs, we’d all be comfortable, right?

original: "to do two things at once is to do neither." it's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the roman writer publilius syrus, although you know how these things are, he probably never said it. What i'm interested in, though, is — is it true? i mean, it's obviously true for emailing at the dinner table or texting while driving or possibly for live tweeting at ted talk, as well. But i'd like to argue that for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once — or three or even four — is exactly what we should be aiming for.look no further than albert einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.
polished: To do two things at once is to do neither." This brilliant critique of multitasking is often credited to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus—though, as with many quotes, he likely never said it. But my real question is: Is it true? Certainly, it applies to emailing at dinner, texting while driving, or live-tweeting a TED Talk. Yet I’d argue that for certain important tasks, doing two—or even three or four—things at once is exactly the goal. Take Albert Einstein: in 1905, he published four groundbreaking scientific papers.

original: I know this is going to sound strange, but i think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, i grew up in bethlehem, pennsylvania, the home of bethlehem steel. My father was an engineer, and when i was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home, when i was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build ... A robot.a robot.
polished: I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to be better humans. Growing up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania—home of Bethlehem Steel—my father, an engineer, taught me how things worked. We built projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here’s the go-kart we made—that’s me behind the wheel with my sister and best friend. One day when I was around 10, he came home and announced at dinner that our next project would be... a robot. A robot.

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how i impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.
polished: Sustainability defines the what, where, and how of what is caught. But the who and why matter most to me. I want to know the people behind my meals, how I affect them, and how they affect me. I want to understand why they fish and how they depend on the water’s bounty for their livelihood. Grasping this shifts our view of seafood from a commodity to a chance to heal our ecosystem. It lets us appreciate the seafood we’re lucky to enjoy. So what do we call this? Restorative seafood. While sustainability is about enduring, restoration is about replenishing and progressing.

original: The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of charles dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of dickens's writing that make it so special?dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.
polished: The starving orphan begging for a second helping of gruel. The spinster fading away in her tattered wedding gown. The miser, hardened by greed, haunted by the ghost of Christmas past. Over a century after his death, these remain iconic figures from Charles Dickens’s work. His writing is so distinctive that it inspired its own adjective. But what makes Dickens’s prose truly remarkable? His fiction thrives on suspense, crafted through atmospheric settings, unexpected twists, and lingering mysteries. These elements captivated his audience, leaving them eager for more. Originally, his tales were serialized—released in affordable literary journals chapter by chapter—before being compiled into books.

original: Shah rukh khan: courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the biggest achievers have in common. These are those brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What looks to us an unconquerable sea, to our next speaker is an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. polished:
Shah Rukh Khan: Courage, determination, and a single-minded vision—these are the traits shared by the greatest achievers. These are the fearless souls for whom failure is never an option. What seems like an insurmountable challenge to us is merely the stage our next speaker was destined to conquer. Bhakti Sharma: Picture this—a scorching summer afternoon in Rajasthan. A two-and-a-half-year-old clings to her mother on a moped, unaware of their destination. Twenty minutes later, that child finds herself fully submerged in water.

original: I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at oxford now, that we think is going to change the way that computer games and hollywood movies are being made. original: Like a lot of people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and i were obsessed with the women's world cup held in france. Here we are, watching these incredible athletes, the goals were amazing, the games were clean and engaging, and at the same time, outside the field, these women are talking about equal pay, and in the case of some countries, any pay at all for their sport. So because we were mildly obsessed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the spanish-speaking networks in the us was the best place for us to start. And it wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend of mine talks to me and says, "why does it feel like everything i'm seeing is commercials for makeup and household cleaning products and diets?
polished: Like many people worldwide, earlier this summer my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup in France. We watched incredible athletes score amazing goals in clean, engaging matches, while off the field, these women advocated for equal pay—or any pay at all in some countries. Our mild obsession led us to watch the games live, and we chose a Spanish-speaking network in the U.S. as our go-to. A few games in, a friend turned to me and asked, "Why does it feel like everything I'm seeing is ads for makeup, cleaning products, and diets?

original: I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about this culture that lived in micronesia in the early 1900s, called the yap. Now, i want to tell you about the yap because their form of money is really interesting. They use these limestone discs called rai stones. Now, the yap don't actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because rai stones can get to be pretty massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So the yap just keep track of who owns part of what stone.there's a story about these sailors that were transporting a stone across the ocean when they ran into some trouble and the stone actually fell in.
polished: Let me tell you about the future of money. It begins with a story of the Yap, a culture in Micronesia during the early 1900s. Their form of currency was fascinating—they used massive limestone discs called Rai stones. Unlike modern coins, the Yap didn’t physically exchange these stones due to their enormous size; some weighed up to four tons and spanned 12 feet. Instead, they simply recorded ownership. There’s even a tale of sailors transporting one across the ocean when disaster struck, and the stone sank.

original: You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging?this was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of salem, massachusetts between february 1692 and may 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth.salem was settled in 1626 by puritans, a group of english protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of salem. Battles with their native american neighbors and groups of french settlers were commonplace.
polished: You’ve been accused of a crime you didn’t commit. Proving your innocence is impossible. If you maintain your innocence, you’ll likely be convicted and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession—or risk a public hanging? This was the dilemma faced by those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They fell victim to supernatural paranoia, misguided religious fervor—and a justice system that prized repentance over truth. Salem was founded in 1626 by Puritans, English Protestants. Life there was strict and isolated. Conflicts with Native American neighbors and French settlers were common.

original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished: Currently, hundreds of thousands of people await life-saving transplants for organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers. Sadly, donor organs fall far short of meeting this demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could produce new, customized organs? This is the vision behind bioprinting, an emerging field in regenerative medicine. While complex organs remain beyond our reach, simpler tissues—such as blood vessels and nutrient-exchange tubes—are already achievable. Bioprinting is akin to 3D printing, building three-dimensional structures layer by layer, but with biological materials.

original: Good afternoon, i'm proud to be here at tedxkrakow. I'll try to speak a little bit today about a phenomenon which can, and actually is changing the world, and whose name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are monty python lovers, a monty python type of sketch. Here it is.it is december 15, 2010. Somebody gives you a bet: you will look at a crystal ball, and you will see the future; the future will be accurate. But you need to share it with the world. Ok, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look at the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national tv, in a top show, and you tell the story.
polished: Good afternoon, I'm honored to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I'll discuss a phenomenon that is actively transforming our world: people power. I'll begin with an anecdote—or for Monty Python fans, a sketch-like scenario. Imagine it's December 15, 2010. Someone offers you a bet: peer into a crystal ball to see an accurate future, but you must share it with the world. Curiosity wins—you accept. One hour later, you're on a national TV show, recounting what you saw.

original: We're going to begin in 1964. Bob dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. polished:
We begin in 1964. Bob Dylan, 23 years old, is at the peak of his career. Hailed as the voice of a generation, he produces timeless songs at an astonishing pace. Yet a small group of critics accuse him of stealing others' work.  

Fast forward to 2004. Brian Burton, known as Danger Mouse, merges The Beatles' *White Album* with Jay-Z's *Black Album* to create *The Grey Album*. It quickly becomes an online sensation. The Beatles' label responds with cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." Today, *The Grey Album* stands as a groundbreaking remix.

original: Well, that's kind of an obvious statement up there. I started with that sentence about 12 years ago, and i started in the context of developing countries, but you're sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, i think you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to say, "these are places where good teachers won't go." on top of that, those are the places from where trouble comes. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers don't want to go to just those places where they're needed the most.i started in 1999 to try and address this problem with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in new delhi.
polished: Well, that’s a rather obvious observation. I began with that statement nearly 12 years ago, focusing on developing countries, but you’re here from every corner of the world. Picture a map of your country, and you’ll realize that for every nation, you could mark areas where good teachers refuse to work. Worse, these are often the very places where trouble arises. It’s an ironic dilemma—good teachers avoid the regions that need them most. In 1999, I launched an experiment in New Delhi to tackle this issue—a simple yet bold initiative.

original: Currently, most refugees live in the cities rather than in the refugee camps. We represent over 60 percent of the number of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees living in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to spend on programs to help refugees to help themselves. (applause)we always have to leave behind all our possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can help themselves and contribute to the development of their host country.i was born in the city called bukavu, south kivu, in the democratic republic of congo. polished: Currently, most refugees reside in urban areas rather than camps, representing over 60% of refugees worldwide. Given this reality, a paradigm shift is urgently needed. Instead of investing in barriers, funds should support programs empowering refugees to become self-reliant. (Applause) Though we often leave behind possessions, we retain our skills and knowledge. When given the opportunity, refugees can thrive and contribute meaningfully to their host communities. I was born in Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, as the fifth of twelve children.

original: I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? and two: what do you stand for? these are two questions that i always begin my poetry workshops with students because at times, poetry can seem like this dead art form for old white men who just seem like they were born to be old, like, you know, benjamin button or something. And i ask my students these two questions, and then i share how i answer them, which is in these three sentences that go: i am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words i repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, i was doing it in the corner over there. I was making faces.
polished:
Here’s the polished version:  

"I have two questions for you. First: whose shoulders do you stand on? Second: what do you stand for? I always start my poetry workshops with these because poetry can sometimes feel like a dead art form for old white men who seem born to be ancient—like Benjamin Button. I ask my students these questions, then share my own answers in three sentences: I am the daughter of Black writers, descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. These words are my mantra before every poetry performance—I was even reciting them earlier, making faces in the corner.

polished: (Breathes in) (Breathes out) So, I didn’t always make my living from music. For nearly five years after graduating from a respected liberal arts university, this was my day job. (Laughter) I worked as a self-employed living statue called the Eight-Foot Bride, and I love telling people about it because everyone wonders, 'Who are these performers in real life?' (Laughter) Hello. One day, I painted myself white, stood on a box, placed a hat or can at my feet, and whenever someone dropped in money, I gave them a flower—along with intense eye contact. If they refused the flower, I’d add a gesture of sadness and longing as they walked away.

original: On october 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the soviet union launched sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That superlative goes to the v-2 rocket used by germany in missile attacks against allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of world war ii. It wasn't very effective, but, at the end of the war, both the u.s. And u.s.s.r. Had captured the technology and the scientists that had developed it and began using them for their own projects.
polished: On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, humanity's first artificial satellite, into space. This small metal sphere, barely two feet wide, ignited an eighteen-year space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R., reshaping history. However, Sputnik wasn’t the first human-made object in space. That distinction belongs to Germany’s V-2 rocket, deployed in WWII’s final years for missile strikes against Allied cities. Though ineffective, the V-2’s technology—and its creators—were seized by both superpowers post-war, fueling their own ambitious programs.

I'm a voracious reader, a reader who deals with ian mcewan down to stephanie meyer. I have read the twilight tetralogy. polished: I am a cultural omnivore, whose daily commute is soundtracked by an iPod filled with Wagner and Mozart, pop diva Christina Aguilera, country singer Josh Turner, gospel artist Kirk Franklin, concertos, symphonies, and more. I'm a voracious reader, equally immersed in Ian McEwan and Stephanie Meyer—yes, I’ve read the entire *Twilight* series. My home theater is my sanctuary, where I indulge in DVDs, video on demand, and endless television. From *Law & Order: SVU* to Tina Fey’s *30 Rock* and the unfiltered drama of *Judge Judy*—"The people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final"—I savor it all.

original: [citizens of the world][we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale][please stand by for a message from ... ][the secretary-general of the united nations antónio guterres]the climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. polished: [Citizens of the world,][we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale.][Please stand by for a message from...][the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres.] The climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time—and losing. Impatience grows, especially among youth, over global inaction. Greater ambition is needed from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and individuals worldwide. I’m encouraged by the launch of TED Countdown. Your influence and ideas can accelerate progress toward a carbon-neutral world by 2050. This is our only path to avoiding the worst impacts of global heating. The tools, science, and resources exist. Now, we must race forward with political will and determination.

original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.
polished: Menstruation—a simple word describing a natural biological process—is burdened by centuries of stigma, reduced to a topic many still whisper about. But why? Right now, over 800 million women worldwide are menstruating. None of us would exist without it, yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject. From my experience and that of countless women, I can say it’s exhausting. Exhausting to furtively pull out a pad hidden in a brown paper bag, tuck it into your pocket mid-class, and rush discreetly to the washroom. Exhausting to sit through lessons or meetings, pretending everything’s fine while enduring agonizing cramps.

original: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, canada's boreal forest. It stretches right across northern canada, in labrador, it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world: the george river caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when i was there, i couldn't find one of them, but you have the antlers as proof.all across the boreal, we're blessed with this incredible abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are one of the most endangered ecosystems. They're absolutely critical ecosystems, they clean air, they clean water, they sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and they're home to a huge diversity of species.
polished: The world's largest and most devastating industrial project lies within Canada's boreal forest, the most intact forest ecosystem on Earth. Spanning northern Canada into Labrador, it shelters the planet's last major wild caribou herd—the George River herd, with roughly 400,000 animals. Though I couldn't spot any during my visit, their antlers remain as evidence. Across this boreal region, we're graced with extraordinary wetland abundance. Globally among the most threatened ecosystems, wetlands perform vital functions: purifying air and water, storing greenhouse gases, and supporting immense biodiversity. These fragile landscapes are absolutely crucial to our planet's health.

original: Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other— they didn’t even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction.one day, while the supreme spirit yaya was out in his gardens, deminan and his brothers snuck into yaya’s house. polished: Before the world of humans began, there existed a divine realm of fields, plains, and gardens. Four brothers roamed this celestial domain, with no family but each other—not even knowing their parents. One brother, Deminan, stood apart, his skin covered in painful scabs. He often wondered why he alone bore this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya tended his gardens, Deminan and his brothers sneaked into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they discovered a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they peered inside, they accidentally dropped it.

original: So, i had graduated seven years ago from berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and i had gone to a career fair here on campus, where i'd gotten an interview with a start-up called theranos. And at the time, there wasn't really that much information about the company, but the little that was there was really impressive. Essentially, what the company was doing was creating a medical device where you would be able to run your entire blood panel on a finger-stick of blood. So you wouldn't have to get a big needle stuck in your arm in order to get your blood test done. So this was interesting not only because it was less painful, but also, it could potentially open the door to predictive diagnostics.
polished: Seven years ago, I graduated from Berkeley with dual degrees in molecular and cell biology and linguistics. At a campus career fair, I secured an interview with a startup called Theranos. Back then, there wasn’t much information about the company, but what little existed was impressive. Their goal was to develop a medical device capable of running a full blood panel using just a finger-stick sample. This meant no more painful needle draws for blood tests. Beyond reducing discomfort, the technology held promise for advancing predictive diagnostics, making it a compelling innovation.

original: My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing, specializing in the polar regions, began when i was four years old, when my family moved from southern canada to northern baffin island, up by greenland. There we lived with the inuit in the tiny inuit community of 200 inuit people, where [we] were one of three non-inuit families. And in this community, we didn't have a television; we didn't have computers, obviously, radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the inuit, playing. The snow and the ice were my sandbox, and the inuit were my teachers. And that's where i became truly obsessed with this polar realm.
polished: My journey to becoming a polar specialist, photographing and specializing in the polar regions, began at age four when my family moved from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. There, we lived among the Inuit in a small community of 200, where we were one of only three non-Inuit families. Without television, computers, radio, or even a telephone, I spent all my time outdoors with the Inuit, playing. The snow and ice were my sandbox, and the Inuit were my teachers. That’s where my deep obsession with the polar realm truly began.

original: We're seen as the organization that is the bucket for failed social policy. I can't define who comes to us or how long they stay. That's our job: contain them, control them.over the years, as a prison system, as a nation, and as a society, we've become very good at that, but that shouldn't make you happy. Today we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. We have more black men in prison today than were under slavery in 1850.
polished: We're viewed as the organization that catches the fallout of failed social policies. I can't determine who comes to us or how long they stay. We take in those for whom nothing else has worked—people who slipped through every other safety net. When others can't contain them, we must. That's our role: containment and control. Over time, as a prison system, a nation, and a society, we've mastered this. But that's no cause for pride. Today, we incarcerate more people per capita than any other nation. More Black men are in prison now than were enslaved in 1850.

original: I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the rosetta spacecraft. To escort and land the probe on a comet, this has been my passion for the past two years. In order to do that, i need to explain to you something about the origin of the solar system.when we go back four and a half billion years, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Along with that, what we now know as planets, comets and asteroids formed. What then happened, according to theory, is that when the earth had cooled down a bit after its formation, comets massively impacted the earth and delivered water to earth. polished: I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the Rosetta spacecraft—to escort and land the probe on a comet. This has been my passion for the past two years. To understand this mission, I must first explain something about the solar system's origin. Four and a half billion years ago, a cloud of gas and dust existed. At its center, our Sun formed and ignited, while planets, comets, and asteroids took shape around it. According to theory, once Earth cooled after its formation, comets bombarded it, delivering water. They likely also brought complex organic material, which may have sparked the emergence of life.

original: Chris anderson: hello, ted community, welcome back for another live conversation. It's a big one today, as big as they get. You know, when we created this "build back better" series our thought was how could we address issues arising out of the pandemic, how could we imagine building back from that. But the events of this past week, the horrific death of george floyd and the daily protests that have followed, i mean, they provided a new urgency which we, of course, simply have to address. I mean, can we build back better from this? i think before we can even start to answer that question, we just have to seek to understand the immensity of this moment.whitney pennington rodgers: that's right, chris.
polished:
Chris Anderson: Hello, TED community, welcome back for another live conversation. Today’s discussion is monumental—as significant as they come. When we launched the "Build Back Better" series, our focus was addressing challenges emerging from the pandemic and envisioning recovery. But the events of this past week—the tragic death of George Floyd and the ensuing protests—have introduced an urgent new dimension we must confront. Can we truly build back better from this? Before answering, we must first grasp the profound gravity of this moment.  

Whitney Pennington Rodgers: That's right, Chris.

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, the U.S. president embarked on a three-day camping trip in California’s Yosemite Valley. Theodore Roosevelt slept among towering sequoias, weathered a snowstorm, and shared campfire conversations with his host, conservationist John Muir. Though Roosevelt adored the outdoors, Muir’s invitation had a greater purpose: Yosemite was under threat. Despite gaining protected status in 1864, the valley faced overdevelopment by 1903. It stood at the center of a long-standing effort to preserve land for both conservation and public enjoyment—goals far harder to achieve than to declare. The conflict over Yosemite traces back to the 1849 Gold Rush, when miners flooded the Sierra Nevada foothills in search of gold.

original: Hello. This is my first trip, first time in life i'm outside of the walls of gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause)my ambition always was to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free to fly the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, i live in gaza, there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing i can do is just to look up to the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire on the front or on the roof of our homes.
polished: Hello. This is my first trip—the first time in my life I’ve stepped outside Gaza’s walls. I’m overjoyed to be here. (Applause.) My dream was always to become a pilot, to soar through the sky and feel that boundless freedom. But it never happened. I live in Gaza, where there’s no airport, and every border is sealed shut. We’re trapped in one of the world’s largest prisons. All I can do is gaze at the sky. Some days, we’re lucky to have electricity for four or five hours. When it’s cold, we light fires outside or on our rooftops.

original: I am sorry i cannot show you my face, because if i do, the bad guys will come for me.my journey started 14 years ago. I was a young reporter. polished: I’m sorry I can’t show you my face, because if I do, the bad guys will come for me. My journey began 14 years ago. I was a young reporter fresh out of college when I got a scoop—a seemingly simple story about police officers taking bribes from street hawkers. As a new journalist, I wanted to cover it differently to maximize impact, since everyone knew it was happening, yet nothing was being done. So I decided to pose as a street seller. While working undercover, I gathered hard evidence. The impact was incredible—what many call immersion journalism or undercover journalism.

There can be a disconnect between broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the often specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. So how can you avoid being misled by grabby headlines?the best way to assess a headline’s credibility is to look at the original research it reports on. polished: One simple vitamin may lower your risk of heart disease. Eating chocolate can reduce stress in students. A new drug extends lives for patients with a rare condition. Health headlines like these appear daily, often contradicting one another. There’s often a gap between flashy headlines and the nuanced, incremental findings of the studies they reference. So how can you avoid being misled? The best approach is to examine the original research behind the claims. We’ve created hypothetical research scenarios for each of these headlines. Keep watching for the first example’s explanation, then pause to answer the question. These are simplified scenarios.

original: So, when i was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from ethiopia. And one day my mom asked, "what day should we put for their birthday?" "uh, the day they were born, obviously?" ridiculous question. And then my mom said, "well, kristen, neither of your little brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" mind blown. Now, 20 years later, i'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, i try to solve this problem globally.so what do birth certificates have to do with international development?
polished: When I was 14, my family was adopting my little brothers from Ethiopia. One day, my mom asked, "What day should we put for their birthday?" "The day they were born, obviously," I replied, thinking it was a silly question. She then explained, "Kristen, neither of your brothers has a birth certificate. How do you suggest we find out?" That moment changed everything. Now, 20 years later, I’m still working on it—but instead of solving just my brothers' missing birth certificates, I’m tackling this issue globally. So, what do birth certificates have to do with international development?

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished: Imagine if you could connect your mind to a machine offering lifelong, unparalleled pleasure. If given the choice, would you embrace such an existence? This is the question philosopher Robert Nozick explored through his thought experiment, the Experience Machine. It challenges us to envision a world where scientists have created a device capable of simulating reality—delivering only pleasure and no pain. The catch? You must abandon reality permanently, though the difference would be imperceptible. Your simulated experiences would feel entirely real, replacing life’s natural highs and lows with ceaseless euphoria. Sounds perfect, doesn’t it?

original: I would like to tell you about the most embarrassing thing that has ever happened to me in my years of working as a palliative care physician. This happened a couple of years ago. I was asked as a consultant to see a woman in her 70s — retired english professor who had pancreatic cancer. I was asked to see her because she had pain, nausea, vomiting ... When i went to see her, we talked about those symptoms and in the course of that consultation, she asked me whether i thought that medical marijuana might help her. I thought back to everything that i had learned in medical school about medical marijuana, which didn't take very long because i had learned absolutely nothing.
polished: I’d like to share the most embarrassing moment from my years as a palliative care physician. A few years ago, I was consulted to see a woman in her 70s—a retired English professor with pancreatic cancer. She was experiencing pain, nausea, and vomiting. During our discussion about her symptoms, she asked if medical marijuana might help. I reflected on everything I’d learned about it in medical school, which didn’t take long because I’d learned absolutely nothing.

original: For the past 24 years, i have been a firefighter in huntington, west virginia. As firefighters, my team and i are tasked with saving lives and property from such disasters as car wrecks, house fires and also life-threatening medical emergencies. I am a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession.and 10 years ago, i decided to increase my medical knowledge and i received a nursing degree. That was because it became clear that the next big threat facing not only my city, but other cities around the country, was not the one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry, as a firefighter, put out the fire and leave, feeling like you have made a difference and everything is ok.
polished: For the past 24 years, I have served as a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. My team and I are responsible for saving lives and property from disasters like car accidents, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. As a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession, I faced unique challenges. A decade ago, I chose to expand my medical expertise by earning a nursing degree. This decision stemmed from recognizing that the next major threat to my city—and others nationwide—wasn’t the single-event disaster where firefighters arrive, resolve the crisis, and depart. Instead, it required deeper, sustained intervention.

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished: Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon is part of a natural cycle, present in all living things: in soil, oceans, the atmosphere, and deep underground rocks. When plants and organisms die, much of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants absorb it again. Over millions of years, some carbon from ancient trees and marine life forms rocks or fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events, such as volcanic eruptions, release carbon trapped in rock. Human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release this ancient carbon. Today, humans emit about 60 times more carbon annually than all the world’s volcanoes combined.

original: Even nature's most disgusting creatures have important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches coming towards them?yet one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies relates to robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, because of their shape, they actually roll automatically to their side to go through this artificial test bit of grass.robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
polished: Even nature's most repulsive creatures hold vital secrets, but who would welcome a swarm of cockroaches? Yet a key distinction between natural and human technologies lies in robustness. Robust systems remain stable in complex, unfamiliar environments. Astonishingly, cockroaches can self-stabilize while traversing rough terrain. Equipped with jet packs or subjected to disturbances like earthquakes, their finely tuned legs enable self-stabilization without cognitive input. They navigate complex landscapes like grass effortlessly, maintaining stability. We observed a novel behavior: their body shape allows them to automatically roll sideways to maneuver through artificial grass patches. Robust systems can execute multiple functions with a single structure—revealing yet another remarkable adaptation.
